metadata.name: Suspicious GUP Usage
metadata.comment: Detects execution of the Notepad++ updater in a suspicious directory, which is often used in DLL side-loading attacks

batch.sql: SELECT * FROM process_activity WHERE time BETWEEN CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() AND (lower(activity_id) = lower('1') AND endswith(lower(process.name), lower('\\gup.exe')) AND NOT (endswith(lower(process.name), lower('\\program files\\notepad++\\updater\\gup.exe')) OR endswith(lower(process.name), lower('\\program files (x86)\\notepad++\\updater\\gup.exe')) OR contains(lower(process.name), lower('\\users\\')) AND (endswith(lower(process.name), lower('\\appdata\\local\\notepad++\\updater\\gup.exe')) OR endswith(lower(process.name), lower('\\appdata\\roaming\\notepad++\\updater\\gup.exe')))))

output.summary: Detects execution of the Notepad++ updater in a suspicious directory, which is often used in DLL side-loading attacks

metadata.objective: False positive: Execution of tools named GUP.exe and located in folders different than Notepad++\updater Reference: https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2018/09/apt10-targeting-japanese-corporations-using-updated-ttps.html
